    React Introduction


    React JavaScript library

    React (also known as React.js or ReactJS) is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Facebook and a community of individual developers and companies.

    React JavaScript library

    React (also known as React.js or ReactJS) is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Facebook and a community of individual developers and companies.

    React Wikipedia Reference.

    Yarn

    Yarn is a new JavaScript package manager built by Facebook, Google, Exponent and Tilde. Yarn is only a new CLI client that fetches modules from the npm registry. It is not intended as a replacement for NPM. Its purpose is to solve a handful of problems that these teams faced with npm, namely:

    • Installing packages wasn’t fast/consistent enough, and
    • There were security concerns, as npm allows packages to run code on installation.

    yarn.lock

    The yarn.lock file performs the same functions as npm-shrinkwrap.json in that an exact version of a dependant package is defined rather than the potential range of dependencies that can exist in the package.json file (E.g. “fstream”: “~1.0.2”).

    The big difference between yarn.lock and npm-shrinkwrap.json is that yarn.lock is automatically created and npm-shrinkwrap.json must be manually created with npm shrinkwrap.

    Semantic Versioning (semver)

    It’s worth understanding semver in NPM in order to understand why it’s important to have an automatically generated yarn.lock file. Semantic versioning as the publisher of a package,

    • 0.0.1: not yet stable\ready for initial release.
    • 1.0.0: ready to be shared with others.
    • 1.0.1: minor bug fix.
    • 1.1.0: new functionality.
    • 2.0.0: new major release. Not backwards compatible.

    As the consumer of a package, you specify which kinds of updates you want to accept. If you only want patch updates. E.g. 1.0.0->1.0.1 and not 1.0.0->1.1.0;

    • 1.0.x
    • ~1.0.4

    If you need to download only new features and not anything that may not be backwards compatible. E.g. 1.0.0->1.1.0 and not 1.0.0->2.0.0;

    • 1.x
    • ^1.0.4

    Parallel Installation

    Whenever npm or Yarn needs to install a package, it carries out a series of tasks. In npm, these tasks are executed per package and sequentially, meaning it will wait for a package to be fully installed before moving on to the next. Yarn executes these tasks in parallel, increasing performance.

    Cleaner Output

    By default npm is very verbose. For example, it recursively lists all installed packages when running npm install . Yarn on the other hand, isn’t verbose at all. When details can be obtained via other commands, it lists significantly less information with appropriate emojis (unless you’re on Windows).

    CLI Differences

    Yarn also has different commands. Some npm commands were removed, others modified and a couple of interesting commands were added.

    yarn global

    Install packages globally on your operating system. yarn global is a prefix used for a number of commands like add, bin, list and remove. They behave identically to their normal versions except that they use a global directory to store packages.

    Just like npm, project-specific dependencies shouldn’t need to be installed globally.

    Note: Unlike the –global flag in npm, global is a command which must immediately follow yarn. Entering yarn add global package-name will add the packages named global and package-name locally instead of adding package-name globally.

    $ yarn global <add/bin/list/remove/upgrade> [--prefix]

    To view the location of the globally installed packages;

    $ yarn global bin
/usr/local/bin
$

    yarn install

    The npm install command will install dependencies from the package.json file and allows you to add new packages. yarn install only installs the dependencies listed in yarn.lock or package.json, in that order.

    yarn add [-dev]

    Similar to npm install , yarn add allows you to add and install a dependency. As the name of the command implies, it adds a dependency, meaning it automatically saves a reference to the package in the package.json file, just as npm’s --save flag does. Yarn’s --dev flag adds the package as a developer dependency, like npm’s --save-dev flag.

    Install yarn Globally

    $ npm install -g yarn

    The yarn doco can be found here

    React Dev Tools

    React Developer Tools is a Chrome DevTools extension for the open-source React JavaScript library. It allows you to inspect the React component hierarchies in the Chrome Developer Tools.

    You will get a new tab called React in your Chrome DevTools. This shows you the root React components that were rendered on the page, as well as the subcomponents that they ended up rendering.

    By selecting one of the components in the tree, you can inspect and edit its current props and state in the panel on the right. In the breadcrumbs you can inspect the selected component, the component that created it, the component that created that one, and so on.

    If you inspect a React element on the page using the regular Elements tab, then switch over to the React tab, that element will be automatically selected in the React tree.

    To install the React Dev Tools;

    $ npm install -g react-devtools

    Live Server

    This is a little development server with live reload capability. Pages reload automatically after changes to files thus helps to speed up development. To install live server globally;

    $ npm install live-server -g
$ live-server -v
$ live-server 1.2.0

    Live server usage examples are shown below. More info on live server can be found here.

    Babel Code Conversion

    Babel is a toolchain that is mainly used to convert ECMAScript 2015+ code into a backwards compatible version of JavaScript in current and older browsers or environments. The most common use for Babel is to take features from ES6 & ES7 and compiling them down to ES5.

    In following examples, will use babel to convert JSX to JavaScript.

    Install Babel CLI

    $ npm install babel-cli@6.24.1 -g
$ babel --help
Usage: babel [options] <files ...>
Options:
  -f, --filename [filename]            filename to use when reading from stdin - this will be used in source-maps, errors etc
  --retain-lines                       retain line numbers - will result in really ugly code
  --no-highlight-code                  enable/disable ANSI syntax highlighting of code frames (on by default)
  --presets [list]
  ...

    More info on babel can be found here.
    You can test the converstion of things like JSX to JavaScript here.

    First React App

    Setup the Public Assets Location

    The public folder will contain all the assets that will be served up.

    • Setup a /public/ folder in the app root directory.
    $ cd ~/Documents/Development/react-course/indecision-app/
$ mkdir public
    • Create a /public/index.html;
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
    <head>
        <meta charset='utf-8'>
        <title>Some Title</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      <div id='app'></div> <!-- this div will be used as a target for a JSX template. -->
    </body>
</html>
    • Test that the page can be served up using live-server;
    $ live-server public

    Include React Libs & Pub Scripts

    • Setup a /public/scripts/ folder. The public folder will contain all the assets that will be served up.
    $ cd ~/Documents/Development/react-course/indecision-app/public
$ mkdir scripts
    • Create a /public/scripts/app.js file. Resulting structure should look like this;

    • Add react libraries and public JS to the body of /public/index.html via a CDN (unpkg.com).
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
    <head>
        <meta charset='utf-8'>
        <title>title</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      <div id='app'></div>
      <script src="https://unpkg.com/react@16.0.0/umd/react.development.js"></script>
      <script src="https://unpkg.com/react-dom@16.0.0/umd/react-dom.development.js"></script>
      <script src="/scripts/app.js"></script>
    </body>
</html>
    • Test that the React libraries are available via the Chrome dev console.
      • React : {Children: {…}, Component: ƒ, …}
      • ReactDOM: {createPortal: ƒ, hydrate: ƒ, render: ƒ, …}

    Note:

    • If you don’t see the React and ReactDOM variables return within the console, there is likely a typo in the script tags in index.html.
    • If you see something like;

      ‘Refused to execute script from ‘http://127.0.0.1:8080/scripts/app.js’ because its MIME type (‘text/html’) is not executable, and strict MIME type checking is enabled: Unexpected token’

      this will be due to a app.js pathing problem in the index.html. Remember, the paths in the HTML are relative to the public folder.

    JSX First Look

    JavaScript XML (JSX) is a JavaScript syntax extension and has been provided by React. The following example shows the creation of a template variable that has been assigned some JSX data.

    • Update the /public/scripts/app.js with the following;
    // /public/scripts/app.js
var template = <p>This is JSX from app.js!</p>;
var appRoot = document.getElementById('app');
ReactDOM.render(template,appRoot);

    So, what’s going on here?

    • We have created a template variable containing JSX.
    • We have an appRoot variable containing the ‘app’ HTML element.
      In this example it will be the <div id=’app’></div> element within index.html.
    • We then use ReactDOM.render() to render the JSX into the index.html. The ReactDOM.render() method takes two arguments;
      1. The JSX template you want to render. In this example it is the template variable.
      2. The DOM element. This is the ID of the HTML element where this template should be rendered.

    But there’s a problem! If you run the app you will receive the error;

    ‘Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token’

    The error is being thrown from the JSX expression, <p>This is JSX from app.js!</p>. This is because JSX expressions are not part of javascript, it’s an extension. The code needs to be compiled down to javascript. To compile the JSX down to JavaScript we will use Babel.

    JSX to JavaScript Conversion

    To get rid of the ‘Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token’ error seen in the previous section we need to convert the JSX into something that the browser can understand. This is where Babel comes into play.

    Using the JSX example above, babel would convert as shown below;

    //JSX. browser does not understand this,
var template = <p>This is JSX from app.js!</p>;

//ES5. browser does understand this,
var template = React.createElement(
  "p",
  null,
  "This is JSX from app.js!"
);

    You can generate the converted code with the Babel compiler here.

    It is possible to take the converted JSX and insert it into the app.js to bypass the error however this is a far from efficiant practice.

    In the following section we will include Babel in the project to perform automatic conversions.

    Project Setup with Babel

    In order to get Babel to perform automatic JSX conversion in our project we have to add various plugins and presets. A preset is just a group of Babel plugins. One of which is the React preset. You can test the various presets on the babel conversion page.

    All future JSX examples will assume that the project has been configured with the following Babal presets;

    • React
    • ENV (includes by default);
      • es2015
      • es2016
      • es2017

    To setup the project to use the desired Babel presets, start by generating a package.json file;

    $ cd ~/Documents/Development/react-course/indecision-app
$ yarn init

    There should now be a package.json file in the ~/Documents/Development/react-course/indecision-app/

    • Should return something like;
    {
  "name": "indecision-app",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "dependencies": {
    "babel-cli": "^6.24.1",
    "npm": "^6.4.1"
  },
  "devDependencies": {},
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "author": "Me",
  "license": "ISC"
}
    • Should also see a package.json in the project with the json shown above.
    • Install Babel presets;
    $ yarn add babel-preset-react@6.24.1
$ yarn add babel-preset-env@1.5.2
    • After running the above commands the package.json file should have two new dependencies;
      • “babel-preset-env”: “1.5.2”
      • “babel-preset-react”: “6.24.1”
    • There should also now be a yarn.lock file.
    • Create a new src directory in the project with a new app.js. This file will contain all the react code while /public/scripts/ will contain auto-generated code.
    • Update /src/app.js with;
    console.log('App is running.');
var template = <p>This is JSX from app.js!</p>;
var appRoot = document.getElementById('app');

ReactDOM.render(template, appRoot);
    • Clear out the /public/scripts/app.js file. It should be empty.
    • Compile the JSX.
    $ babel src/app.js --out-file=public/scripts/app.js --presets=env,react --watch
    • The –watch argument behaves a little like live-server. It will keep the babel compiler running and any changes made to /src/ will automatically be updated into /public/scripts/
    • If you want to run this on different OS’s you would need to regenerate the node_modules. You can delete the modules and run npm install to re-download all your dependencies.
